name: (E)-dec-5-enyl acetate

name: Blood meal
Description: Dried pig blood used as a game repellent and plant biostimulant
Example pests controlled: Game particularly deer and rabbits; Growth; Stress
Example applications: Deciduous and conifer trees; Orchard trees; Ornamental plants; Lettuce; Romatoes; Peppers
Uses: Crop protection; Forestry; Woodland management Target pests Game particularly deer and rabbits Target host Deciduous and conifer trees; Orchard trees; Ornamental plants Farming system suitability - CAS RN 90989-74-5 EC number 292-731-9 CIPAC number 909 US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name blood meal PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Used as a fertiliser in organic farming; USEPA minimum risk pesticide Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Reddish-brown powder with a faint sweet odour
Efficacy & activity: Whilst blood meal is normally used as a game repellent or fertiliser there is evidence of a biostimulant effect. Several studies have reported its value in reducing plant stress from heat and drought. For example, in one study porcine blood-derived protein hydrolysate alleviated the negative effects of drought stress on tomato growth by stimulating antioxidant systems. In another study with lettuce plants subjected to extreme heat and cold, blood meal was shown to reduce damage. Efficacy & activity: Chitosan is a proven plant biostimulator. It has been shown in both field trials and the lab that it can stimulate plant growth, and abiotic stress tolerance. Chitosan has been shown to improve the tolerance of tomatoes to heat stress, increasing productivity. In a study with lettuce, a chitosan-based biostimulant improved yield (biomass) and quality (chlorophyll & total phenolic content, & antiradical activity). In a field experiment with wheat it was clearly demonstrated that foliar treatment of chitosan significantly increased the grain yield, as well as increasing the photosynthetic pigments, total soluble sugar, proline, free amino acid total carbohydrates, antioxidant activities, phenol, flavonoids, and mineral content of wheat plants. Significant increases of different endogenous phytohormones auxins, abscisic acid, gibberellins, and cytokinins were also observed along with improved nutritive values, carbohydrates, proteins & antioxidant compounds. However, studies have also shown that the effectiveness of chitosan biostimulants depends on different chitosan-based structures and concentrations as well as the plant species and developmental stage. Example pests controlled: Tetranychidae pests including the red spider mite, two-spotted spider mite, tarsonemid mites and carmine mite
Example applications: Protected crops grown at elevated temperatures and some field crops where temperatures are high

name: Aphidoletes aphidimyza
Description: An aphid predator used as a biocontrol agent for all species of aphid
Example pests controlled: Aphids
Example applications: Glasshouse crops including peppers, tomatoes; Ornamental including flowers, trees and shrubs; Top fruit
Uses: Glasshouse crop protection; Interior landscape management; Park & garden management; Orchard management Target pests Aphids Target host Glasshouse crops including peppers, tomatoes; Ornamental including flowers, trees and shrubs; Top fruit Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Aphidoletes aphidimyza PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism Related substances & organisms Aphidius colemani
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle The adults are small, less than 1/8 inch long, black, delicate flies with a lifespan of about 10 days. They feed on aphid honeydew. Larvae are small, bright orange maggots. The female flies deposit orange eggs within the aphid colony. Larvae inject a toxin into aphids leg joints to paralyse them and then suck out the aphid body contents through a hole bitten in the thorax. The larvae drop to the ground and burrow into the soil to pupate. Description: A small black parasitic wasp that can be used for the biological control of cockroaches
Example pests controlled: Cockroaches including the American Cockroach (Periplaneta americana), Smokybrown Cockroach (Periplaneta fuliginosa), the Harlequin Cockroach (Neostylopyga rhombifolia) and the Florida Cockroach (Eurycotis floridana)
Example applications: Interior situations such as warehouses, industrial properties and in domestic situations
Uses: Interior situations such as warehouses, industrial properties and in domestic situations Target pests Cockroaches including the American Cockroach (Periplaneta americana), Smokybrown Cockroach (Periplaneta fuliginosa), the Harlequin Cockroach (Neostylopyga rhombifolia) and the Florida Cockroach (Eurycotis floridana) Target host - Farming system suitability Not normally used for agricultural production CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Aprostocetus hagenowii Ratzeburg PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle A small black wasp 2-3 mm in length. Females laytheir eggs inside the eggs of the cockroach. The young instars of the parasitoid feed upon the developing young cockroaches and finally pupate, still within the egg case of the cockroach. Fully developed wasps emerge from the egg case to mate and restart the cycle. name: Bangasternus orientalis
Description: A small phytophagous weevil that can be used for the biological control of thistle particularly the yellow star thistle
Example pests controlled: Yellow star-thistle (Centaurea solstitialis); Purple star-thistle (Centaurea calcitrapa)
Uses: Grassland and pasture management Target pests Yellow star-thistle (Centaurea solstitialis); Purple star-thistle (Centaurea calcitrapa) Target host Grassland; Rangeland; Pasture Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Bangasternus orientalis (Capiomont) PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle Adult is 4-6mm long and body is covered with fine, light hairs. The female lays her eggs close to the thistle flowerhead. Larvae consume the flower and developing seeds thus stopping germination of the next plant generation. Larvae go on to pupate on the flowerhead remains. Host specific. One generation per year and adults live approximately 2 months. Dislikes cool climates. name: Bathyplectes curculionis
Description: A parasitic wasp that can be used for the biocontrol of the alfalfa weevil that is a serious economic pest of lucerne in many parts of the world including North America
Example pests controlled: Alfalfa weevil (Hypera postica); Egyptian alfalfa weevil (Hypera brunnipennis)
Uses: Crop protection Target pests Alfalfa weevil (Hypera postica); Egyptian alfalfa weevil (Hypera brunnipennis) Target host Lucerne Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Bathyplectes curculionis (Thompson) PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle Small black wasps about 3mm in length with stout bodies. Adult wasps lay their eggs within the weevil larvae, as the eggs hatch they feed internally on the larvae killing it. Only one parasitoid can develop inside the host weevil eventually emerging to spin a cocoon. These cocoons are 3-4mm long, oval shaped, brown in colour wit ha cream central band. Typically only one generation of weevil occur each year. name: Blood meal
Description: Dried pig blood used as a game repellent and plant biostimulant
Example pests controlled: Game particularly deer and rabbits; Growth; Stress
Example applications: Deciduous and conifer trees; Orchard trees; Ornamental plants; Lettuce; Romatoes; Peppers
Uses: Crop protection; Forestry; Woodland management Target pests Game particularly deer and rabbits Target host Deciduous and conifer trees; Orchard trees; Ornamental plants Farming system suitability - CAS RN 90989-74-5 EC number 292-731-9 CIPAC number 909 US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name blood meal PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Used as a fertiliser in organic farming; USEPA minimum risk pesticide Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Reddish-brown powder with a faint sweet odour
Efficacy & activity: Whilst blood meal is normally used as a game repellent or fertiliser there is evidence of a biostimulant effect. Several studies have reported its value in reducing plant stress from heat and drought. For example, in one study porcine blood-derived protein hydrolysate alleviated the negative effects of drought stress on tomato growth by stimulating antioxidant systems. In another study with lettuce plants subjected to extreme heat and cold, blood meal was shown to reduce damage. name: Bracon cushmani
Description: A small parasitic wasp that can be used for the biological control of various moth pests

Example applications: Grapes; Pistachio nuts; Almonds; Peach; Cherry; Apple; Other tree fruits
Uses: Crop protection Target pests Obliquebanded leaf roller (Choristoneura rosaceana); Grape leaffolder (Desmia funeralis) Target host Grapes; Pistachio nuts; Almonds; Peach; Cherry; Apple; Other tree fruits Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Bracon cushmani (Muesebeck) PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism Related substances & organisms Bracon hebetor Bracon gelechiae
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle Very small wasps (~ 0.1mm long) with a long slender abdomen. The adult female paralyse and deposit up to 8 eggs in individual instar moth larvae. name: Chitosan hydrochloride
Description: An animal derived fungicide which, structurally, is a straight-chain copolymer composed of D-glucosamine and N-acetyl-D-glucosamine. It is used to control root rots and to improve seed germination, root development and general plant health.
Example pests controlled: Root rot; Growth; Vigour; Stress
Uses: Crop protection Target pests Powdery mildews and botrytis species. Also active against some nematodes. Target host Many field crops, ornamentals, and turf Farming system suitability Suitable for use in all farming systems where approved for use in that country CAS RN 70694-72-3 EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code 128930 PubChem CID - Molecular mass 1526.45 PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name poly-D-glucosamine CAS name β-(1,4)-2-amino-2-deoxy-D-glucose Forever chemical - Other status information Approved via EU & UK 'Basic substance' legislation (Article 28 of Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009); USEPA minimum risk pesticide Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state White powder Related substances & organisms optiCHOS
Efficacy & activity: Chitosan is a proven plant biostimulator. It has been shown in both field trials and the lab that it can stimulate plant growth, and abiotic stress tolerance. Chitosan has been shown to improve the tolerance of tomatoes to heat stress, increasing productivity. In a study with lettuce, a chitosan-based biostimulant improved yield (biomass) and quality (chlorophyll & total phenolic content, & antiradical activity). In a field experiment with wheat it was clearly demonstrated that foliar treatment of chitosan significantly increased the grain yield, as well as increasing the photosynthetic pigments, total soluble sugar, proline, free amino acid total carbohydrates, antioxidant activities, phenol, flavonoids, and mineral content of wheat plants. Significant increases of different endogenous phytohormones auxins, abscisic acid, gibberellins, and cytokinins were also observed along with improved nutritive values, carbohydrates, proteins & antioxidant compounds. However, studies have also shown that the effectiveness of chitosan biostimulants depends on different chitosan-based structures and concentrations as well as the plant species and developmental stage. Example applications: Soft fruit; Top fruit; Hops; Ornamentals

name: Dacnusa sibirica
Description: A parasitic wasp that preys on leaf minsers and used for their biological control
Example pests controlled: Tomato leafminers (Liriomyza bryoniae , Liriomyza huidobrensis , Liriomyza trifolii); Chrysanthemum Leafminer (Phytomyza syngenesiae)
Example applications: Protected crops especially vegetables and ornamentals
Uses: Crop protection Target pests Tomato leafminers (Liriomyza bryoniae , Liriomyza huidobrensis , Liriomyza trifolii); Chrysanthemum Leafminer (Phytomyza syngenesiae) Target host Protected crops especially vegetables and ornamentals Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Dacnusa sibirica Telenga PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle The adult wasp is dark brown to black in colour and is 2-3 mm long. Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle The adult wasp 6-12mm long, black with lighter colored abdomen and legs. The larvae are a light green. name: Microlarinus lareynii
Description: A phytophagous beetle that can be used to control puncture vines
Example pests controlled: Puncture vine (Tribulus terrestris); Jamaica feverplant (Tribulus cistoides); Kallstroemia species (e.g. Kallstroemia californica, Kallstroemia grandiflora)
Uses: Land management Target pests Puncture vine (Tribulus terrestris); Jamaica feverplant (Tribulus cistoides); Kallstroemia species (e.g. Kallstroemia californica, Kallstroemia grandiflora) Target host Pasture; Rangeland Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Microlarinus lareynii Jacquilin du Val PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism Related substances & organisms Microlarinus lypriformis
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle Adults are small brownish weevils, 4-5mm long, covered with stiff grayish hairs. Larvae are C-shaped grubs. Female weevils chew into the side of a young puncture vine bur, deposit eggs into the seed and seal it with faecal material. Weevils grubs develop inside the seed and pupate therein. This activity significantly reduces seed production. name: Microlarinus lypriformis
Description: A phytophagous beetle that can be used to control puncture vines
Example pests controlled: Puncture vine (Tribulus terrestris)
Uses: Land management Target pests Puncture vine (Tribulus terrestris) Target host Pasture; Rangeland Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Microlarinus lypriformis (Wollaston) PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism Related substances & organisms Microlarinus lareynii
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle Adults are small brownish weevils, 4-5mm long. Larvae are C-shaped grubs. Larvae and adults both consume puncturevine. Feeding within stems and root crowns inhibits the ability of the plants to transport and store vital nutrients, and heavy feeding can cause stem breakage. name: Rhinocyllus conicus
Description: A phytophagous weevil that can be used for the biological control of noxious thistles
Example pests controlled: Musk or nodding thistle (Carduus nutans) but may consume other thistles including native species
Uses: Land management Target pests Musk or nodding thistle (Carduus nutans) but may consume other thistles including native species Target host Rangeland; Pasture Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Rhinocyllus conicus Froelich PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle The adult is dark brown/black in colour with a short-snout and is around 10mm long. Females lay their eggs close to the the bracts of the thistle flower head. Newly hatched larva burrow into the flower head and feeds on the flower parts and developing seeds. This significantly reduces seed production and can cause severe plant damage. Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle The life cycle takes around a week and consists of an egg stage, four juvenile stages, and an adult stage. name: Zeuxidiplosis giardi
Description: A small midge that can be used for the biological control of St Johns Wort
Example pests controlled: St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum)
Uses: Crop protection; Land management; Forestry Target pests St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum) Target host Pasture: Rangeland; Various crops Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Zeuxidiplosis giardi (Kieffer) PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information Most countries require a licence to be issued before non-native macro-organisms may be released as biocontrol agents Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Living organism
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle A small (~2-3mm long) red-brown coloured midge. Larvae are around 2mm long and red-orange coloured. Female lays eggs on the plant. Newly hatched larvae enter leaf bud and their feeding leads to the formation of a gall. The plant loses vigor, foliage, and root development. Infected plants may die in the dry seasons due to their incapability to store and obtain moisture. This reduces growth and seedling survival. name: Beauveria bassiana strain R444
Description: A naturally occuring fungal parasite used to control pests on a wide variety of food and ornamental crops
Example pests controlled: Two-spotted spider mite; Whitefly; False Codling Moth; Cabbage moth (Plutella xylostella) larvae; Thrips; weevils
Example applications: Greenhouse-grown ornamentals; Tomatoes; Stone fruits; Berries; Fruiting vegetables; Curcubit vegetables; Leafy vegetables; Brassicas; Cannabis; Herbs and spices
Uses: Plant protection Target pests Two-spotted spider mite; Whitefly; False Codling Moth; Cabbage moth (Plutella xylostella) larvae Target host Greenhouse-grown ornamentals; Fruiting vegetables; Curcubit vegetables; Leafy vegetables; Brassicas; Berries; Cannabis; Herbs and spices Farming system suitability Suitable for IPM where approved for use CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Beauveria bassiana strain R444 PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) UNF Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Fungus. The formulated product is an off-white granular solid.
Efficacy & activity: Trial results also show good efficacy against weevils, wire worm, thrips and other agricultural insect and mite pests. Best results seen at temperatures 25-30 DegC. Appearance and life cycle Filamentous fungal spores. Life cycle consists of two phases. Firstly, the parasitic phases whereby the spores germinate on the cuticle and then penetrate the insect germinates, and colonise with the formation of blastospores. Secondly, during the saprophytic phase spores are disseminated into soil. name: Cryptococcus albidus
Description: A naturally occurring fungi used to control storage rot fungi in top fruit
Example pests controlled: Storage rot fungi particularly Penicillium spp., Mucor spp. and Botrytis spp.
Uses: Crop protection - storage; Post-harvest treatment Target pests Storage rot fungi particularly Penicillium spp., Mucor spp. and Botrytis spp. Target host Top fruit - apples and pears Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Cryptococcus albidus (Saito) Skinner PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) BM02 Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Fungus
Efficacy & activity: - Appearance and life cycle There are two distinct forms of this fungus: sexual and asexual. The asexual form exists as yeast that divides by narrow-based budding. The sexual forms exist in nature in two mating types. When opposite types mate, meiosis occurs, resulting in chains of basidiospores, which are the infectious particles. name: Entyloma ageratinae

Uses: Forestry; Woodland mangement; Land management Target pests Mistflower (< i>Ageratina riparia) Target host Forests; Amenity grassland; Rangeland Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Entyloma ageratinae Barreto and Evans PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) BM02 Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Fungus

name: Gibberellins
Description: Plant hormones that regulate growth and influence various developmental processes including stem elongation, germination, dormancy and flowering
Example pests controlled: Russet; Cracking; Quality
Uses: Crop protection; Yield enhancement Target pests Russet; Cracking Target host Apples; Pears Farming system suitability - CAS RN 8030-53-3 Alternative/old CAS RN 173269-32-4; 510-75-8 EC number 207-406-9 / 208-117-0 CIPAC number 904 US EPA chemical code 043801 PubChem CID - Molecular mass 331.4 (mean) PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name (3S,3aR,4S,4aR,7R,9aR,9bR,12S)-12-hydroxy-3-methyl-6-methylene-2-oxoperhydro-4a,7-methano-3,9b-propanoazuleno[1,2-b]furan-4-carboxylic acid + (3S,3aR,4S,4aR,7R,9aR,9bR,12S)-12-hydroxy-3-methyl-6-methylene-2-oxoperhydro-4a,7-methano-9b,3-propenoazuleno[1,2-b]furan-4-carboxylic acid CAS name (1α,2β,4αβ,4bβ,10β)-2,4a-dihydroxy-1-methyl-8-methylenegibbane-1,10-dicarboxylic acid 1,4a-lactone + (1α,2β,4αβ,4bβ,10β)-2,4a-dihydroxy-1-methyl-8-methylenegibb-3-ene-1,10-dicarboxylic acid 1,4a-lactone Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not known Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) - Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance None identified Physical state White crystalline solid Related substances & organisms gibberellic acid potassium gibberellate
Efficacy & activity: The effectiveness of gibberellins at enhancing plant growth has been extensively proven from lab and field studies and known for over a century. However, not all plants respond to the same extent or in the same way. In a study with dwarf pea plants, which naturally have short internodes, treatment with gibberellins produced significantly elongated stems. Seedless grapes treated with Gibberellins had significantly increased yields, enhancing both the size and quality of the fruit. In the brewing industry, gibberellins are used to stimulate the germination of barley seeds, which is a crucial step in the production of malt. name: Kinetin
Description: Botanical plant growth regulator which is a type of cytokinin, used to increase yields, blossom production and desirable growth effects.
Example pests controlled: Growth; Stress; Nematodes
Example applications: Variety of crops; Fruit trees: Ornamentals; Nuts
Uses: Crop protection; Yield enhancement Target pests Nematodes Target host Variety of crops; Fruit trees: Ornamentals Farming system suitability Suitable for use in all farming systems where approved for use in that country CAS RN 525-79-1 EC number 208-382-2 CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code 116801 PubChem CID 3830 Molecular mass 215.22 PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name 6-furfurylamino-9H-purine CAS name N-(2-furanylmethyl)-1H-purin-6-amine Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not known Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state White crystalline solid Related substances & organisms 6-isopentenyl aminopurine zeatin mepiquat chloride cytokinin kinetin hydrochloride
Efficacy & activity: Studies have shown that kinetin can significantly improve growth parameters, including seedling and root lengths, fresh and dry weights, and antioxidant activities. For example, applying 30 mg/L of kinetin has been found to enhance growth, floral, and root traits under prolonged irrigation intervals. In a study with almonds the addition of kinetin resulted in statistically significant yield improvements. Almond nut set and retention levels also improved. name: Metarhizium brunneun strain Cb15-III
Description: A naturally occurring mitosporic fungus that can be used to control wireworms in various crops and also shown to have biostimulant activity
Example pests controlled: Wireworms (Agriotes spp.); Growth; Stress
Uses: Crop protection Target pests Wireworms (Agriotes spp.) Target host Potatoes; Asparagus Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Metarhizium brunnewn strain Cb15-III PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not known Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) - Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Fungus
Efficacy & activity: As an insecticide and biostimulant Metarhizium brunneum is well studied. As an insecticide research has shown efficacies of 30-70%. Strong evidence also exists regarding its ability to reduce heat and water stress, as well as alleviating nutrient poverty. Under stressed conditions wheat plants inoculated with M. brunneum improved yield (seed weight). Biostimulation efficacy has been shown to be strongly dose dependent. name: Potassium gibberellate
Description: A natural plant growth regulator with a variety of uses including improving fruit set, increasing berry size and controlling fruit maturity
Example pests controlled: Growth; Stress
Uses: Growth; Stress Target pests - Target host Seedless grapes Vegetables; Cereals Farming system suitability - CAS RN 125-67-7 EC number 204-749-6 CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID 71299661 Molecular mass 384.50 PIN (Preferred Identification Name) potassium;(1R,2R,5S,8S,9S,10R,11S,12S)-5,12-dihydroxy-11-methyl-6-methylidene-16-oxo-15-oxapentacyclo[9.3.2.15,8.01,10.02,8]heptadec-13-ene-9-carboxylate IUPAC name potassium;(1R,2R,5S,8S,9S,10R,11S,12S)-5,12-dihydroxy-11-methyl-6-methylidene-16-oxo-15-oxapentacyclo[9.3.2.15,8.01,10.02,8]heptadec-13-ene-9-carboxylate CAS name potassium (1S,2S,4aR,4bR,7S,9aS,10S,10aR)-1,2,4b,5,6,7,8,9,10,10a-decahydro-2,7-dihydroxy-1-methyl-8-methylene-13-oxo-4a,1-(epoxymethano)-7,9a-methanobenz[a]azulene-10-carboxylate (1:1) Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state White crystalline solid Related substances & organisms gibberellic acid gibberellins
Efficacy & activity: As gibberellic acid, it has been proven as a biostimulant by both extensive lab and field studies over the last century. In a study with rice, gibberellic acid treatment was shown to significantly increased plant height, earlier flowering, and higher seed yield. Application to grapevines has been found to enhance berry size and improve cluster compactness. This leads to higher market value and better quality produce. Gibberellic acid treatment to wheat has been shown to increase stem elongation, leading to taller plants with more biomass. With tomatoes, gibberellic acid has been shown to promote early flowering and fruit set, leading to an extended harvest period and increased total yield. name: Trichoderma harzianum strain T78
Description: A biological fungicide, growth promoter and biostimulant used to control various fungal pathogens and mazimise crop productivity
Example pests controlled: Many common soil and foliar pathogens including Fusarium wilt; Growth; Stress; Yield
Uses: Crop protection; Yield enhancement Target pests Many common soil and foliar pathogens including Fusarium wilt Target host Tomato; Vineyards; Melons Farming system suitability Suitable for use in all farming systems where approved for use in that country CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Trichoderma harzianum strain T78 PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) BM02 Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Fungus Related substances & organisms Trichoderma afroharzianum strain T-22 Trichoderma harzianum strain T39 Trichoderma asperellum strain ICC012 Trichoderma asperellum strain T11 Trichoderma virens strain GL-21 Trichoderma stromaticum
Efficacy & activity: Efficacy as a fungicide is proven by field and lab trials. As a biostimulant it enhances the absorption of nutrients that are naturally present in the soil. name: Artemisia vulgaris oil
Description: A plant extract, shown in lab studies, to have herbicidal and insecticidal activity as well as acting as a crop biostimulant.
Example pests controlled: Pigweed Amaranthus retroflexus ; Yellow-fever mosquito Aedes aegypti ; Red flour beetle (Tribolium castaneum); Growth; Stress
Uses: Crop protection; Public health Target pests Pigweed Amaranthus retroflexus ; Yellow-fever mosquito Aedes aegypti ; Red flour beetle (Tribolium castaneum) Target host Maize; Cereals; Stored products Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Artemisia vulgaris extract PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state A brown liquid when formulated which is comprised mainly of oxygenated monoterpenes including beta-pinene, alpha-pinene, camphor, and 1,8-cineole Related substances & organisms Artemisia absinthium extract alpha-pinene 1,8-cineole
Efficacy & activity: Efficacy appears to be variable and species specific. As a herbicide, lab studies have shown that, at concentrations from 7.5% to 10% w/v, it can inhibit seed germination, seedling emergence and growth of the weed redroot pigweed (Amaranthus retroflexus), without affecting maize performance. In other species (e.g. carrot & rapeseed), the liquor acts as a biostimulant, improving seedling germination and growth. However, in other species (e.g. onion, tomato, lettuce) no significant effect has been seen. There are a few published studies available which support claims that corn steep liquor may protect plants from specific abiotic and biotic stresses (extreme temperatures, nutritional limitations, salinity, drought, pathogens). Study results showed that application of the liquor increased aerial biomass and leaf area of various agricultural and horticultural crops under normal and saline conditions. In addition, studies have observed improved stress resiliance when grown in hydroponic systems with the liquor. name: Caulerpa sertularioides extract
Description: A plant derives substance that appears to have some application as an insecticide and antimicrobial and may have potential as a biostimulant.
Example pests controlled: Asian citrus psyllid Diaphorina citri ; Stress
Uses: Crop protection Target pests Asian citrus psyllid Diaphorina citri Target host Citrus Farming system suitability - CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Caulerpa sertularioides extract PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state The seaweed is pale to dark-green in colour and can grow up to 2m in length. It has feather-like fronds that arise from a common stolon. Related substances & organisms Sea algae extract Ecklonia maxima extract Kappaphycus alvarezii extract Chlorella vulgaris extract Sargassum muticum extract Caulerpa racemosa extract
Efficacy & activity: The extract is best known for its antimicrobial properties. For example, citrus greening, disease of citrus caused by a vector-transmitted pathogen, was reduced due to a reduction of the pest Diaphorina citri following treatment with C. sertularioides . There are very few studies published regarding the effectiveness of the tropical/subtropical seaweed Caulerpa sertularioides as a biostimulant. Those that do report positive effects on yield and improved tolerance to biotic and abiotic stress. However, there are studies that report that seaweed extracts made from C. sertularioides applied at higher concentrations (1%) negatively impacted tomato seed germination. name: Gibberellins
Description: Plant hormones that regulate growth and influence various developmental processes including stem elongation, germination, dormancy and flowering
Example pests controlled: Russet; Cracking; Quality
Uses: Crop protection; Yield enhancement Target pests Russet; Cracking Target host Apples; Pears Farming system suitability - CAS RN 8030-53-3 Alternative/old CAS RN 173269-32-4; 510-75-8 EC number 207-406-9 / 208-117-0 CIPAC number 904 US EPA chemical code 043801 PubChem CID - Molecular mass 331.4 (mean) PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name (3S,3aR,4S,4aR,7R,9aR,9bR,12S)-12-hydroxy-3-methyl-6-methylene-2-oxoperhydro-4a,7-methano-3,9b-propanoazuleno[1,2-b]furan-4-carboxylic acid + (3S,3aR,4S,4aR,7R,9aR,9bR,12S)-12-hydroxy-3-methyl-6-methylene-2-oxoperhydro-4a,7-methano-9b,3-propenoazuleno[1,2-b]furan-4-carboxylic acid CAS name (1α,2β,4αβ,4bβ,10β)-2,4a-dihydroxy-1-methyl-8-methylenegibbane-1,10-dicarboxylic acid 1,4a-lactone + (1α,2β,4αβ,4bβ,10β)-2,4a-dihydroxy-1-methyl-8-methylenegibb-3-ene-1,10-dicarboxylic acid 1,4a-lactone Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not known Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) - Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance None identified Physical state White crystalline solid Related substances & organisms gibberellic acid potassium gibberellate
Efficacy & activity: The effectiveness of gibberellins at enhancing plant growth has been extensively proven from lab and field studies and known for over a century. However, not all plants respond to the same extent or in the same way. In a study with dwarf pea plants, which naturally have short internodes, treatment with gibberellins produced significantly elongated stems. Seedless grapes treated with Gibberellins had significantly increased yields, enhancing both the size and quality of the fruit. In the brewing industry, gibberellins are used to stimulate the germination of barley seeds, which is a crucial step in the production of malt. name: Kinetin
Description: Botanical plant growth regulator which is a type of cytokinin, used to increase yields, blossom production and desirable growth effects.
Example pests controlled: Growth; Stress; Nematodes
Example applications: Variety of crops; Fruit trees: Ornamentals; Nuts
Uses: Crop protection; Yield enhancement Target pests Nematodes Target host Variety of crops; Fruit trees: Ornamentals Farming system suitability Suitable for use in all farming systems where approved for use in that country CAS RN 525-79-1 EC number 208-382-2 CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code 116801 PubChem CID 3830 Molecular mass 215.22 PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name 6-furfurylamino-9H-purine CAS name N-(2-furanylmethyl)-1H-purin-6-amine Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not known Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state White crystalline solid Related substances & organisms 6-isopentenyl aminopurine zeatin mepiquat chloride cytokinin kinetin hydrochloride
Efficacy & activity: Studies have shown that kinetin can significantly improve growth parameters, including seedling and root lengths, fresh and dry weights, and antioxidant activities. For example, applying 30 mg/L of kinetin has been found to enhance growth, floral, and root traits under prolonged irrigation intervals. In a study with almonds the addition of kinetin resulted in statistically significant yield improvements. Almond nut set and retention levels also improved. name: Maize glutens
Description: A protein derived from maize kernels and used to control a range of weeds pre-emergence on non-food crops
Example pests controlled: Black medic; Crabgrass; Creeping bentgrass; Smart weed; Dandelions; Redroot bigweed; Plaintain; Purslane; Lambs quarter; Foxtail; Barnyardgrass,; Bermuda grass
Uses: Lawn and turf management Target pests Black medic; Crabgrass; Creeping bentgrass; Smart weed; Dandelions; Redroot bigweed; Plaintain; Purslane; Lambs quarter; Foxtail; Barnyard grass,; Bermuda grass Target host Lawns; Turf Farming system suitability IFM - where regulatory approvals exist CAS RN 66071-96-3 EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code 100137 PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Maize glutens PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information US GRAS. Uses: Growth; Stress Target pests - Target host Seedless grapes Vegetables; Cereals Farming system suitability - CAS RN 125-67-7 EC number 204-749-6 CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID 71299661 Molecular mass 384.50 PIN (Preferred Identification Name) potassium;(1R,2R,5S,8S,9S,10R,11S,12S)-5,12-dihydroxy-11-methyl-6-methylidene-16-oxo-15-oxapentacyclo[9.3.2.15,8.01,10.02,8]heptadec-13-ene-9-carboxylate IUPAC name potassium;(1R,2R,5S,8S,9S,10R,11S,12S)-5,12-dihydroxy-11-methyl-6-methylidene-16-oxo-15-oxapentacyclo[9.3.2.15,8.01,10.02,8]heptadec-13-ene-9-carboxylate CAS name potassium (1S,2S,4aR,4bR,7S,9aS,10S,10aR)-1,2,4b,5,6,7,8,9,10,10a-decahydro-2,7-dihydroxy-1-methyl-8-methylene-13-oxo-4a,1-(epoxymethano)-7,9a-methanobenz[a]azulene-10-carboxylate (1:1) Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state White crystalline solid Related substances & organisms gibberellic acid gibberellins
Efficacy & activity: As gibberellic acid, it has been proven as a biostimulant by both extensive lab and field studies over the last century. In a study with rice, gibberellic acid treatment was shown to significantly increased plant height, earlier flowering, and higher seed yield. Application to grapevines has been found to enhance berry size and improve cluster compactness. This leads to higher market value and better quality produce. Gibberellic acid treatment to wheat has been shown to increase stem elongation, leading to taller plants with more biomass. With tomatoes, gibberellic acid has been shown to promote early flowering and fruit set, leading to an extended harvest period and increased total yield. name: Reynoutria sachalinensis extract
Description: A natural plant extract (containing emodin, physcion and resveratrol) which can be used as a preventative treatment for various plant fungal and bacterial infections
Example pests controlled: Grey mold (Botrytis cinerea); Powdery mildew (Uncinula necator, Leveillula taurica, Podosphaera macularis); Mildews; Canker; Growth; Vigour; Yield
Example applications: Protected ornamentals; Protected glasshouse crops including tomatoes, cucumbers; Fruit including strawberries, grapes; Wheat; Curcubits
Uses: Crop protection Target pests Grey mould (Botrytis cinerea); Powdery mildew (Uncinula necator, Leveillula taurica, Podosphaera macularis); Mildews; Canker Target host Protected ornamentals; Protected glasshouse crops including tomatoes, cucumbers; Fruit Farming system suitability Suitable for use in all farming systems where approved for use in that country CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code 055809 PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Reynoutria sachalinensis extract PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) P05 Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state The extract is an olive green to yellow brown coloured granular solid comprised of a variable and complex mix of botanical substances including emodin, physcion and resveratrol plus glucosides
Efficacy & activity: Extensively studied, the exogenous application of Reynoutria sachalinensis extract has been demonstrated to provide protection against bacterial and fungal diseases for a variety of plants against bacterial and fungal diseases. In addition, the extract appears to have a stimulating effect on the germination and initial growth of wheat grains. In trials with greenhouse-grown, extract-treated cucumbers. yields were at least as high as fungicide-treated plants. R. sachalinensis extract applications enhanced yield up to 49% over the control. name: Sea algae extract
Description: Aqueous extracts of various species of seaweed (e.g. Sargassum) that can be used as a plant growth regulator and biostimulant for various horticultural crops
Example pests controlled: Growth; Vigour; Stress
Uses: Crop protection; Yield enhancement Target pests - Target host Legumes; Carrots Farming system suitability Suitable for use in all farming systems where approved for use in that country CAS RN - EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Sea algae extracts PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Green-brown coloured liquid Related substances & organisms Ascophillum nodosum extract 24-epibrassinolide Ecklonia maxima extract Durvillea potatorum extract Sargassum muticum extract Chlorella vulgaris extract
Efficacy & activity: Sea algae extracts have been extensively studied as biostimulants and a significant body of evidence exists demonstrating improved plant growth, nutrition, quality, yield and stress tolerance (drought, salt conditions). Generally, overall plant perfomance improves following application including increased root growth & mineral uptake, as well as enhanced chlorophyll content. Various different seaweed extracts have been used in product formulations with brown algae the most commonly used. However, efficacy has been shown to be dependant on various factors including the source of seaweed, the extraction method utilised, how it is stored and formulated. name: Triacontanol
Description: A natural chemical that acts as a phytohormone which is used in commercial horticulture as a plant growth regulator and biostimulant
Example pests controlled: Growth; Quality traits; Vigour; Yield; Stress
Example applications: Ornamental plants including roses; Cotton; Tomato; Chilli peppers; Rice; Peanuts; Potato; Grapes
Uses: Commercial horticulture Target pests - Target host - Farming system suitability - CAS RN 593-50-0 EC number 209-794-5 CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID 68972 Molecular mass 438.81 PIN (Preferred Identification Name) triacontan-1-ol IUPAC name triacontan-1-ol CAS name n-triacontanol Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state White powdery solid
Efficacy & activity: Triacontanol as a biostimulant is well studied and shown to positively affect plant phenology. A vineyard study identified a physiological response with vines treated with triacontanol with grapes having higher enological parameters (sugars, total titrable acidity and citric acid content) than the non-treated at every stage. Triaconanol treated grapes reached full maturity earlier than the non-treated. There was also a positive effect on must (grape juice) microbial ecology important for winemaking. In another study triacontanol was shown to be a potent alleviator of stress induced by salt and heavy metal contamination in plants. name: Yucca schidigera extract
Description: An extract from the leaves, stems and roots of the Yucca schidigera plant comprised of natural plant steroidal saponins which has some biostimulant, fungicidal and bactericidal activity
Example pests controlled: Seed-borne pathogens e.g. Leptosphaeria sacchari , Fusarium spp., Cladosporium spp.; Growth; Vigour; Stress
Example applications: Arable crops; Leafy vegetables; Seed potatoes; Fruit; Dogs; Cats; Poultry; Birds
Uses: Crop protection Target pests Seed-borne pathogens e.g. Leptosphaeria sacchari , Fusarium spp., Cladosporium spp. Target host Arable crops; Leafy vegetables; Seed potatoes; Fruit Farming system suitability - CAS RN 90147-57-2 Alternative/old CAS RN 223749-05-1 EC number 290-449-0 CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass - Chemical name Yucca schidigera extract PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name - CAS name - Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not applicable Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not applicable Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Liquid
Efficacy & activity: Despite the commercial use of yucca extract as a plant biostimulant limited data appears to be available regarding the efficacy of it as a biostimulant. However, it has been shown to promote germination and early vigour under drought/osmotic and salt stress induced either by sodium chloride or lithium chloride. name: Zeatin
Description: Botanical plant growth regulator used to increase yields, blossom production and desirable growth effects. Also demonstates activity against some nematodes.
Example pests controlled: Growth; Nematodes; Yield; Stress
Example applications: Variety of crops; Fruit trees; Ornamentals
Uses: Crop protection; Yield enhancement Target pests Nematodes Target host Variety of crops; Fruit trees; Ornamentals Farming system suitability Suitable for use in all farming systems where approved for use in that country CAS RN 1637-39-4 EC number - CIPAC number - US EPA chemical code - PubChem CID - Molecular mass 219.25 PIN (Preferred Identification Name) - IUPAC name 2-methyl-4-(9H-purin-6-ylamino)but-2-en-1-ol CAS name (2E)-2-methyl-4-(1H-purin-6-ylamino)-2-buten-1-ol Forever chemical - Other status information - Relevant Environmental Water Quality Standards - Herbicide Resistance Class (HRAC MoA class) Not known Herbicide Resistance Class (WSSA MoA class) Not known Insecticide Resistance Class (IRAC MoA class) Not applicable Fungicide Resistance Class (FRAC MOA class) Not applicable Examples of recorded resistance - Physical state Off-white to yellow crystalline powder Related substances & organisms 6-isopentenyl aminopurine kinetin cytokinin
Efficacy & activity: Zeatin has been used to promote plant growth for a long time and there is extensive research demonstrating its effectiveness. In one study, wheat seeds pretreated with Zeatins or demonstrated improved plant hormonal content, polyamine gene expression, and tolerance to salinity and drought stress. Similarly, maize seeds treated with a zeatin-type cytokinin biostimulator showed significantly improved salt tolerance by enhancing the antioxidant system and photosynthetic efficiency. Zeatin also increased the growth and biochemical parameters of an oregano crop.
